title: married-woman-claimed-single-pocket-60-000-benefits
story: Claire Robertson obtained pound, in tax credits from  to  after she informed the authorities she was living at home as a single woman.Robertson, , began the wrongful claim in August  and carried on claiming cash she was not entitled to, under her maiden name of Wells, until March last year.But following an investigation, it emerged Robertson had married her husband in September  and he was earning an income.Robertson, of Dolphingstone View, appeared at Edinburgh Sherf Court last Thursday where she pleaded guilty to obtaining pound, in tax credits she was not entitled to.Prosecutor Heather Carmichael told the court that Robertson had ldquonot advised the tax credit office of her marriage and was claiming the cash as a single person.Ms Carmichael said: ldquoShe was residing with her husband and the tax credits should not have been paid on that basis. Her husbandrsquos income had not been taken into account.The fiscal added ldquothe matter came under investigation and the accused was arrested on March  last year.Police arrived at her home with a search warrant and she was taken to St Leonardrsquos Police Station in Edinburgh.Robertsonrsquos solicitor said his client ldquohad made provisions to pay the money back and stated she should be able to pay the money back to HMRC ldquoas soon as possible.The lawyer said Robertsonrsquos husband worked offshore and was ldquonot always at home.He added that Robertson was willing to remortgage the family property in a bid to pay the money back.Sherf Peter Braid deferred sentence until December  for background reports and a restriction of liberty assessment to be prepared.Robertson admitted wrongly obtaining tax credits amounting to pound, by claiming ndash between August ,  and March  last year ndash she was single with no other income when she was married and her husband was earning a salary.

title: express-service-edinburgh-not-viable-says-bus-company
story: Prestonpans Community Councillors invited Prentice Buses and East Coast Buses to a meeting last Tuesday to discuss the possibility of an express bus service at peak times.This followed a Scottish Transport Appraisal Guidancereport into public transport which highlighted that people living in Prestonpans and Cockenzie and Port Seton faced hour-long bus journeys to Edinburgh ndash yet those living . miles further away from the city centre in North Berwick could get a bus to the Capital in just  minutes.But Ian Bieniowski, network performance manager at East Coast Buses, said eventhe company could fill a bus at commuter times, those buses would not cover the running costs of the service.Ross Prentice, owner of Prentice Buses, also attended the meeting.Brian Weddell, community council chair, said: ldquoWe are being treated dferently from the people in North Berwick.ldquoItrsquos not right that you can get into Edinburgh quicker on a bus from North Berwick than Prestonpans.ldquoIrsquom sure you would get the patronage on an express bus at commuter times given the problems with the trains. People are looking for an alternative. Theyrsquore getting into their cars and traffic into Edinburgh is getting busier.Community councillor Gordon Laing said: ldquoI think that the service that we have down here is absolutely dreadful.ldquoWhat you forget with the  [bus] is Seton Sands and in the summertime buses are filled before they even get [to Prestonpans].But Mr Bieniowski said: ldquoEvenwe fill a bus with  people in the morning and  people in the evening, it still needs to cover running costs.ldquoWe do have buses that come out at peak times and then sit in the garage for the rest of the time but we have to minimise the amount of buses that do that. If that happens then itrsquos an asset that is making no money.ldquoAt the moment we donrsquot think it could run commercially as a service. title: tims-tales-christmas-conscience
story: THE onset of winter, with the deadly cold and dark, was something John always dreaded.It was at this time he would make the decision to line up for a place for a hostel bed.John was homeless and he usually slept rough. Hersquod not always been homeless, of course, but people rarely see the person behind the label.The one good thing about winter for him was the approach of Christmas. Peoplersquos consciences seemed to be more sensitive at Christmas time.He was an alcoholic and he blamed himself every day for what he was. But this just fed his sense of worthlessness and kept the cycle going. His earlier le, the lsquonormal onersquo with his we and children, was now a long time ago, but when he slumbered he often re-entered it in his dreams.Especially that last family Christmas, when they were all together. He would re-run that time in his mind, just like his we would watch The Devil Wears Prada over and over and never tire of it. Yes, when he closed his eyes it could seem he was there again.But when he came to his senses, he came back to himself: an unloved man, old before his time, who people ignored and passed in the street without looking at. He usually felt completely invisible. To be fair, some people did stop and talk, usually the same ones.Perhaps they never truly understood just how valued those moments were.He understood it, after all he despised himself, so how could he expect others to feel dferently.Alcohol seemed to be his one real friend, the only one to understand and ease his pain.But St Andrewrsquos Day was approaching and this was his cue to get completely sober.He would feel that tingle inside that people call lsquofeeling Christmassyrsquo. It was a painful, bittersweet emotion for John, and his friend alcohol always offered to help. But he would close his eyes and be strong.It was the one thing in his le where he felt he had not let people down.So he would summon all his strength and draw on who he used to be for those last vestiges of self-belief and refuse the offer of help from his destructive friend.He made it and arrived at the door of the managerrsquos office, clean, sober and ready to work.The manager had no idea John was the same man he passed on a daily basis on the street outside.Admittedly, he did look dferent now, butthe manager had ever paused to look at John or speak to him, then he would surely recognise him. But for once he was glad of his invisibility. If the manager had ever recognised him outside then John would probably lose his job.ldquoYour costume is in the back room. You start in  minutes, said the manager.ldquoThe paperwork came through last week so yoursquore set to go.John knew the routine and got changed.When he sat in his chair, he was transformed. He was Santa.For the next five weeks, he knew he was going to be noticed and even loved. People would speak to him in a kind and almost reverent way, ask him how he was. His beard and red suit wiped away his sense of worthlessness.All that day, families came and he spoke to more people in that one day being Santa than he did the rest of the year being himself.Afterwards, he headed back to the hostel with money in his pocket.His old friend whispered in his ear: ldquoSpend it on me, spend it on me.ldquoMaybe later, but not now, John replied in his head.But the hostel was full and he couldnrsquot find any other place.And so he knew hersquod have to spend a bitter night on the streets.The food van would arrive soon, so he decided to wait for it in the busy centre.As he sat, a young girl came up to him.She just stood and stared. John recognised her.She had been one of the children in his grotto earlier and suddenly a fear gripped him: she might recognise who he really was.ldquoCome away from there, shouted her mother.But the girl still stood, staring at John. Then she smiled. John smiled back.Her father came up and took her by the hand, pulling her away without looking at John.He recognised the father as well.He had been so nice and friendly in the grotto, while his daughter stood with him for a photo.But without his white beard and red suit, John was invisible again.ldquoSpend it on me, spend on me, whispered his old friend again, as John had flashbacks of Afghanistan.ldquoSpend it on me and I will keep you company, nobody  cares, pleaded his friend.Then the girl was in front of him again, smiling.ldquoThis is for you, Merry Christmas when it comes.Her father stood by her, holding her hand, but still not looking at John.It was chocolate. The same chocolate bar shersquod chosen with glee in the grotto.ldquoThank you, said John and the girl left with her dad.Johnrsquos old friend was now silent. The food van arrived and he packed the chocolate under his jacket. It was more than chocolate.Now he had to get through the freezing night.Tomorrow, hersquod be loved again.

title: tims-tales-wise-old-witch
story: HAPPY St Andrewrsquos Day! The results of a poll on peoplersquos favourite Scots word by Scottish Book Trust was revealed this week.So herersquos a tale that includes all the top  favourite Scots words identied in the poll, plus some mair:THE weather matched the young wersquos mood: dreich.By the time she reached the witchrsquos cottage at the foothills of the Lammermuirs, she was soaked.ldquoOch, come in hen, ye look drookit, said the old woman sympathetically. They sat by the fire together.ldquoNoo how can I help ye  asked the old woman.The young we sighed.ldquoI just cannae thole it onymair, she said, getting upset.The old woman listened, waiting for the young woman to compose herself.ldquoItrsquos ma mither-in-law, she bides wi us and, weel, shersquos makin ma le a misery.ldquoHow sae  asked the old woman.ldquoI can dae naethin richt accordin tae her ma cookin is awfu, my hoose is mingin, I canne gie an opinion aboot onythin withoot her sayin the opposite, she treats me asIrsquom glaikit. Irsquom totally scunnerd wi it.ldquoI see, said the witch, ldquoand how can I help ye wi this ldquoI want her oot ma le, I want her deid.ldquoDeid  The witch seemed genuinely shocked.ldquoAye, deid, gone, awa. I just want her oot ma hoose and oot ma le.ldquoWeel, she doenae hae tae be deid fir that, suggested the witch.ldquoAye she does, I dinnae want her aroond. Shersquoll come knocking oan the door. Please can ye help me. I want her deid... er, wi oot it, ye ken, weel sae it isnae murder.ldquoBut it wud be murder ma dear.The young woman bent her head low and began to whisper assomeone might overhear their conversation.ldquoI ken, but ye are a witch, abody says ye hae potions fir onything. Please, I have siller. Mak it look natural. Then me an ma husband can get oan wi oor lives thegither.The witch thought for a moment, then nodded her head.ldquoVery weel, I will help ye, but ye maun dae whit I say.The we smiled with relief: ldquoThank ye.The old woman went ben the hoose to where she kept her herbs and ingredients. The young woman was curious and tried to sneak a look but the witch told her to stay by the fireside until she was finished.Then she came through holding a small bottle of potion.ldquoHere, she said to the we. ldquoThis will dae the trick. Ye maun put ane sma drap o this potion in yer mither-in-lawrsquos tea every day.ldquoBut she maks her ain tea, said the young woman, ldquoshe ay complains I cannae mak tea the proper way.ldquoWeel, ye maun find a way fir her tae allow ye tae mak her tea, said the witch. ldquoThen every day sit wi her as she drinks the tea. She maun drink it a.The we smiled: ldquoHow lang will it tak ldquoOch, mebbes twa months, ye maun use up the hale bottle. Then it will tak effect a few days ater the last drap has been drunk.ldquoTwa months!ldquoAye hen, it must be gradual, otherwise folk will suspect.The young woman clutched the bottle and nodded.ldquoNoo can I hae the siller, asked the witch, and the we willingly paid.ldquoMind tae gie the bottle a wee shoogle afore ye yaise it, the witch advised, ldquoand hud yer wheesht aboot this, or wersquoll baith hang.ldquoO course, said the young woman as she left the witchrsquos house.The weather had lted, as had her mood. Soon her problems would be over, she thought to herself.The witch watched her go, then closed the door. She had a knowing grin on her face.Two months later there was a desperate knocking on the old womanrsquos door. She looked out of the window and saw the young we standing just outwith the cottage, in a terrible state.So she opened her door.ldquoPlease, please help me, begged the young woman.The witch took her inside. The young woman had run all the way and her shawl had become wrapped round her hair, and her dress was dishevelled with the wind.ldquoOch hen, ye are in a richt fankle, sort yersel oot and sit by the fire fir a warm.The young we rearranged her clothes and started to greet as she spoke.ldquoHae ye got an antidote fir the potion please say ye huv, she said.ldquoAn antidote, hen ldquoAye, Irsquove changed ma mind. I gied ma mither-in-law a cup of tea wi the last drap o potion. I watched her drink and then she telt me that I mak a braw cup of tea and that she wis glad her son hud marrit me! It wis in that moment I realised I didnae want her deid!ldquoI see, said the witch. ldquoIrsquom afraid there is nae antidote fir the potion.The young women cradled her head in her hands. ldquoWhit huv I done, what huv I done, she cried to herself.ldquoYe huv got tae ken her, thatrsquos whit yersquove done, said the witch. ldquoAs ye spent time wi her making sure she drank her tea, ye will have talked, am I richt ldquoAye, sobbed the we, ldquoand she listened tae. I ken shersquos an auld witch sometime, er nae offence, but I understand her better noo.The witch smiled. ldquoGuid, she said, ldquonoo ye can gang hame and keep oan huvin the tea thegither, without the potion.ldquoBut shersquos goanie be deid in a few days, sobbed the we.ldquoNaw she isnae, replied the witch, ldquothe potion wis just a few herbs that wouldnae hairm even a wee beastie.ldquoWhat  Ye telt me that it would kill her! protested the we.ldquoNo I didnae, I said it would work ater twa months. And it has. It wis the hatred ye hud that needed kilt, no yer mither-in-law. And the same goes fir her.The young we was so relieved. For a moment she wondered about asking for her money back, but she realised the potion had indeed done its job.Her relationship with her mother-in-law was not always easy, but they had regular cups of tea and chats together, and often they would laugh as they shared memories and stories from le.ldquoThe claes are in a richt bumfle, said the mother-in-law the following day, then she smiled. ldquoBut letrsquos hae oor tea first and we can sort the claes thegither.The we thought to herself that the witch was indeed a wise woman.

story: The team have been working in partnership with Glasgow Science Centre for  months to transform all aspects of the five-star visitor experience and educational resources at the centre, which will reopen completely on Saturday  December followed by a formal launch in January.The learning hub will provide a more engaging and flexible space for inspiring and educating visiting schools, youth and further education groups.The new look learning hub and marine workshops are now available to book and it continues to be used by the charityrsquos weekly wildle watch groups, which are supported by the Scottish Wildle Trust.All of the furniture from the old education classroom has been given to Zero Waste Dunbar, a non-profit social enterprise which aims to keep good things in local circulation, rather than sending them to landfill.Launching the new hub, with young people from the centrersquos Wildle Watch Group, Provost, John McMillan said ldquoThe Scottish Seabird Centre has been a key part of East Lothianrsquos tourism and education offering for nearly  years. title: bay-city-rollers-star-saves-dog-stuck-hole-two-days
story: Bay City Rollers guitarist Stuart lsquoWoodyrsquo Wood was to prove the hero after Kruger, a -year-old black Labrador, went missing on Sunday, November , at about pm.Kruger was on his regular evening walk with owner Janette Murray, , of North Berwickrsquos Rhodes Park, next to the former East Lothian Council depot at Lime Grove.But after going to investigate a scent, he did notwhen called.Janettersquos daughter, -year-old Donna Denton, of the townrsquos Couper Avenue, told the Courier: ldquoHe is a rehomed dog, my mum got him when he was three.ldquoHe is quite timid but very, very friendly and doesnrsquot growl or bark at people ndash I have two kids and hersquos great with them.ldquoIf he does wander off he comes back as soon as he canrsquot see you, he always stays very close.ldquoWe now know the reason he didnrsquot come back this time. The lady from search and rescue said dogs donrsquot bark for help, only when they feel threatened.Kruger was found two days later by Bay City Rollers star Wood at about .am on Tuesday ndash the musician, who was on holiday in North Berwick, was one of  looking for the missing dog.He later posted on Facebook to say ldquothanks for the lovely messages and praising everyone who ldquosearched relentlessly.ldquoWell done everyone ndash we got lucky! he added.The terried dog was eventually found just metres from where he went missing.People all over North Berwick had helped in the search, not realising that Kruger was so close by.One man checked every bunker on the  holes at nearby Glen Golf Club ndashcounting  in total.Kruger gained access to the derelict Lime Grove site through a broken fence.Donna, a childminder and registered nurse, said: ldquoThe hole he fell down was no bigger than  centimetres by  centimetres, he couldnrsquot even lie down in it and was sitting up the whole time he was down there. We couldnrsquot even get our feet in there to help lt him out.ldquoWe phoned the fire brigade as we didnrsquot know what to do but my husband ended up putting a hoist around him and, with another manrsquos help, lting Kruger out with brute force.And she added: ldquoThe area he was found in is such a state and an absolute junkyard ndash therersquos broken bins and slabs everywhere, graffiti etc. It is not safe and is not secure.During the search, Donna contacted the police, SSPCA, search and rescue, the council and Edinburgh Dog and Cat Home, though she said she ldquocouldnrsquot get through to the dog warden at the council.After being rescued and wrapped up in blankets, Kruger was then sent to the vets for a check-up.Donna added: ldquoA man from the council had keys to the gate at the site and let me reverse my car in so I could put Kruger in the back.ldquo[Kruger] was really stf, so we had to carry him into the car and into the vets.ldquoHe was put on some fluids but my mum was able to get him home later that night luckily he wasnrsquot hurt.An appeal to find Kruger posted on social media attracted plenty of attention, something Donna was not expecting.She was full of praise for everyone who helped out, saying: ldquoEveryone was amazing. I had people I didnrsquot know come up to me at the school gates saying they were going to look for Kruger. We were just so lucky it was two mild nights when he was down there.ldquoMy mum will be  next year but was out all day trying to look for him, she didnrsquot want to stop or turn back. She was determined to find him.Since the incident, the hole has been covered with a slab, but the fence still remains damaged.A spokesperson for East Lothian Council said: ldquoIf anyone is aware of an uncovered manhole then itrsquos recommended that they report the exact location to the council, who will investigate further to make it safe.ldquoThis can be done online or via our out of hours number:  .

title: himalayan-lakes-contributing-unprecendented-glacial-melt
story: Their study concluded the glaciers that have flowed into the lakes in recent decades are retreating and thinning much more quickly than others in the region.Previous studies have shown not all glaciers melt in the same way and researchers Dr Owen King and Dr Tobias Bolch, of the School Of Geography And Sustainable Development at St Andrews University, wanted to investigate the unanswered questions posed previously.Mr King said: ldquoEarlier pieces of work tended to show glaciers that flowed into lakes receded at a faster rate than the glaciers that didnrsquot.The scientists used declassied US Hexagon spy satellite imagery, data from the Shuttle Radar Topographic Mission in  and information from modern satellites to examine the relationship between glaciers and glacial lakes since the s.Examining the dferent data sets, the research team found the ice front retreated at more than twice the rate of glaciers that do not flow into lakes.Mr King added: ldquoWe have identied in the latest time period glaciers with lakes retreated nearly  metresa year on average.ldquoFurther enhanced mass loss is very likely should the increases in the total number and area of glacial lakes continue.The glaciers are responsible for as much as  per cent of the ice loss in dferent parts of the mountain range, despite comprising just  to  per cent of the total glacier population.The behaviour of glaciers provides the clearest indication of climatic change in high mountain regions, with long-term atmospheric warming believed to have caused the recession of glaciers across the Himalayas.But why the glaciers that flow into lakes have a higher rate of recession has still to be determined.Mr King said: ldquoThat needs further work. ldquoEasily recognisable mechanisms that could explain the loss is that they can produce icebergs and carve out the big outlet glaciers around Greenland and Antarctica so big chunks of ice fall off the front of the lake, terminating glaciers.ldquoThe lake is warmer than the ice so it melts.Meltwater from glaciers in this region sustains the flow of river systems on which hundreds of millions of people depend for their basic needs.Not all the meltwater instantly drains to downstream catchments and thousands of glacial lakes have developed and continue to expand high in the Himalayas.Until this study, the influence of the lakes on glacier behaviour in the mountain range has not been thoroughly investigated, despite the rapid increase in lake area and number.The results show glacier mass reduction has happened since at least the s and has accelerated this millennium.Glaciers in contact with glacial lakes showed a signicantly higher decrease in mass and are therefore likely to be driving the accelerating loss from the region.Mr King, who has visited the region four times in the last four years, has seen the visible dference.He said: ldquoThe scale of ice loss is really obvious to see. Not just for glaciers that have lakes in front of them, but also those that donrsquot have lakes leave behind signs of how big they used to be and these landforms are a record of where the glacier was in colder times.ldquoNow you can see glaciers have thinned by up to a  metres.Measuring the changes in the Himalayas, which has many of the worldrsquos highest mountains, was no easy feat because of the sheer scale of the landscape.Mr King added: ldquoBecause the mountains are so steep and big, the weathering rates are really high, so therersquos a lot of rock and avalanche debris that works its way down the glaciers. Once that debris gets thick enough, it can act as a bit of a blanket on the glacier it falls on that can protect the ice underneath, so the front generally doesnrsquot recede as much.The change the team documented is the height change in the glacier rather than the change in .Mr Bolch said: ldquoOur results have important implications for future projections of ice loss from the region because the interaction of glaciers and glacial lakes has not previously been considered in future glacier ice loss estimates.

title: cash-reserves-report-reveals-28m-benefit-scotlands-nature-spots
story: Nature reserves are home to important natural habitats and species and give visitors the chance to experience the best of nature in Scotland.However, a new study has found that as well as these recognisable benefits, their worth to the public goes way beyond this.Scottish Natural Heritagehas measured the value of natural capital across its reserves, with the report - the first of its kind in Scotland - revealing that they are worth an estimated pound million to the public each year.The National Nature Reservescapital is made up of numerous climate, tourism, recreation, and health benefits which are present across the ,ha of land owned and managed by SNH.Francesca Osowska, chief executive of the heritage body, claimed the study shows the many advantages of nature as an asset.She said: ldquoThis innovative report vividly illustrates that our nature reserves are providing an outstandingon investment of time, money and resources.ldquoNature is an asset, but one we need to protect and invest in. Key to this is tackling climate change impacts ndash and nature is a solution.ldquoWe need a rich iety of le to be able to sustain food supplies, water and the air we breathe. But itrsquos not just about conservation - enhancing our nature is also part of the solution to the climate emergency.ldquoOur nature reserves are critical to our work of ensuring a nature-rich future for Scotland.Natural capital is the stock of Scotlandrsquos plants, wildle, air, water, and land providing benefits to the people and businesses across the country.SNH claims that assessing the monetary value of natural capital is one way to show how nature provides many benefits to everyone in their everyday lives.Using the natural capital approach to understand naturersquos wider benefits can in turn help businesses and other organisations to make more informed decisions based on a broader picture which includes important environmental factors.The reportrsquos calculations include volunteers contributing , days of work worth a total of pound, SNH land sequestering carbon, mainly through its woodland and saltmarsh habitats, worth poundm and air quality filtration benefits amounting to pound,.Other benefits valued in the report include food, education, renewable energy production, and health and well-being.Annual management costs were estimated at pound.million, which means the estimated benefits of SNH land outweigh the costs by eight to one.The true capital benefits may be much higher, however, as it is not currently possible to measure the other advantages of nature reserves, such as water quality, mental health benefits and flood risk mitigation.The report was welcomed by Dr Deborah Long, chief officer for Scottish Environment LINK, who said the study helped to demonstrate the value of the countryrsquos nature reserves.She said: ldquoScotlandrsquos National Nature Reservesare the jewels in Scotlandrsquos crown as a nature rich nation.ldquoThis new report recognises the monetary value of NNRs and very clearly shows why investment in nature is absolutely crucial in the fight against climate change and the ongoing nature declines, shown in the recent State of Nature Scotland report, and which are happening in Scotland as well as the rest of the world.ldquoIn fact, NNRs are the very best places for nature ndash we all need to be ensuring nature continues to do well in NNRs and the investment not just in managing these reserves but in monitoring how nature is doing is vital.ldquoWith the calculated value of pound million a year, plus the uncalculated value of nature in NNRs for human physical and mental health, as well as ecosystem services like flood protection and clean water, we can very clearly see why investment in nature is fundamental to people and nature and for future generations.SNH is the first public body to publish natural capital accounts for their land in Scotland.It is hoped it may provide a template for other public bodies to follow in considering this approach.Read the full report at https:bit.ly MFWe.To find out more about Scotlandrsquos NNRs, see www.nnr.scot.

title: Rosemary Goring  More female leaders offers hope of safer  stronger world
story: Within a decade of that declaration,   set the wheels spinning on what promises to become a century or more of exceptional chaos and carnage in the middle east, and far beyond.Everyone can get it wrong, especially those whose closely argued ideas are reduced to soundbites. And so it might yet prove with another of Fukuyamas pronouncements. It is his contention that the developed world has recently become more peaceable thanks to women as heads of state and in positions of political influence.Ive often heard people say there would be less conflict and fewer warswomen were in charge. Usually its the middle-aged and elderly ndash mothers, aunts and grandmothers ndash who make this claim. They have never scaled the heights of a male-dominated industry or profession, yet hope that the women they see in charge are imbued with the same gentle, conciliatory and nurturing personalities as themselves. And there, I would suggest, is the snag.Nor am I being unduly cynical. A study by the University of Chicago covering  years of European historyhas shown that not only were queens more inclined to take their country into battle than kings, but also more certain to win.:Nicola Sturgeon announces funding for women leaders schemeIn Victorias day, Britain was at war with some part of the empire, or would-be empire, almost every year of her reign. Three hundred years earlier, Elizabeth I set a gold standard for empire building, showing her mettle as she fought off Spanish incursions, despatching her own conquistadors across the globe, and managing to maintain stability in a precariously inflammable period of religious stre asshe were refereeing a game of croquet.The leader of the Chicago study, Professor Oeindrila Dube, points out that you need only think of Catherine the Great of Russia, or Isabella I of Castile to appreciate that, in previous centuries, royal women were every bit as war-like as men. When circumstances dictated, they didnrsquot hesitate to shed blood.Quite how they felt privately, of course, is another matter. Henry VIIIs daughter, who earned the title Bloody Mary after condemning almost  Protestants and religious dissenters to the pyre, was apparently a warm and affectionate person. What her notorious actions indicate, perhaps, is less a vengeful nature and more the vicious tenor of her times.Even our own Mary Queen of Scots was no peacenik, riding at the head of her troops on more than one occasion and, far from avoiding conflict, at times seeming actively to court it.Professor Dubersquos analysis of royal authority shows that when a queen was in power, she was even more effective than a man. Since she would often work in partnership with her consort, her subjects were effectively getting two warriors for the price of one. There is, however, a great dference between what was required of female rulers in the reign of Victoria and before, and attitudes in modern times.In almost every era prior to our own Elizabethan age, to be a woman was seen to be weak. Debate raged across Europe in the th century about how worthy and capable females could ever beplaced on a throne. John Knox, enraged at Mary of Guise becoming Regent of Scotland, spoke for many when he declared her appointment ldquoas seemly a sight as to put a saddle upon the back of an unruly cow.Given such hostility, itrsquos entirely possible that it was not the assistance of their husbands that made Boudiccas of high-ranking women, but the need to show that they were every bit as aggressive and dangerous as men. The message needed to be sent that anyone who tried to topple them would live ndash albeit briefly ndash to regret it.Margaret Thatcher thrust us into battle in the Falklands where many other prime ministers might have hesitated. You could see her pugnacity, on this and other inflammatory issues, as the problem with Fukuyamas theory. Women who reach the political pinnacle today have had to fight to get there. These are no ordinary women, these are powerful women. Hilary Clintonrsquos personality surely proves that point: her pitch for the presidency showed her to be a great deal more hawk than dove.:Project aims to help women stand for electionYet Fukuyama ndash and others ndash might nevertheless be right in hoping for a less violent futuremore women are at the top table. Nobody has done more to show Germany in a pacic and positively humanitarian light than Angela Merkel, even though she knew her policies risked her political standing in some quarters.To date, the performance of those like Mary Robinson, when she was Irish president, or Helle Thorning-Schmidt when Denmarkrsquos prime minister, or New Zealandrsquos Jacinda Ardern, not to mention Scotlands first minister, offers reason to hope. The ability to compromise, to use diplomatic means to defuse conflict, or find a way around an impasse is, while by no means solely a female quality, certainly one at which we are beginning to excel.Sweeping generalisation though it is, women are undoubtedly less physically combative and martial than men, though potentially nasty nevertheless. It can be seen as early as the school playground that our preferred weaponry is verbal attack and the ability to work stealthily, in ways of which Machiavelli would approve, to undermine the enemy.Irsquove never believed we are nicer than men ndash my experience has been quite the opposite. Yet in the West at least, attitudes in government and society are changing. Itrsquos now possible to be feminine and command respect. Gender no longer signals deficiency. Increasingly, even, it could be seen as a positive advantage.Growing numbers of women are rising through the democratic ranks on the strength of their strategic and negotiating skills, rather than their gung-ho, macho credentials. As a new generation is attracted to these roles, seeing that they no longer need to act tough in order to succeed, then things might just improve. Perhaps it is a reasonable assumption after all that, with more female hands at the tiller, nations will become stronger and safer.

title: greenpeace-calls-ocean-sanctuaries-capture-carbon-save-wildlife
story: A report from Greenpeace highlights the role of the oceans as the worlds largest "carbon sink", storing large amounts of the carbon dioxide put into the atmosphere by human activity, as well as heat as the planet warms.But the continued reliance on burning fossil fuels and the carbon dioxide emissions it causes has led to ocean heating, sea level rises and increasingly acidic seawater - with rapid and large-scale impacts on people and wildle.The changing climate and loss of marine wildle and habitats are threatening the processes that allow the oceans to store carbon, the report warns.There is a need to drastically cut emissions to curb climate change, Greenpeace said.At the same time, a network of ocean sanctuaries, off limits to human activity, would help marine areas be more resilient to the changing climate and protect "blue carbon" stores.These stores of carbon in the seas are the largest on Earth, containing  times the amount of carbon in the atmosphere and  times the amount in land-based vegetation, soils and microbes combined, Greenpeace said.The campaign group is calling on governments to agree a global ocean treaty in  to safeguard the worlds oceans, and to commit to protecting at least % of the oceans by  when they meet at a key nature conference next year, the UN Convention on Biological Diversity in Beijing.The poles, whale hotspots, coral reefs, mangroves and seagrass meadows should be among the priorities for protection, the report said.Louisa Casson, an oceans campaigner at Greenpeace UK, said: "The climate crisis is an ocean crisis."The ocean is fundamental to keeping our planet healthy, but for too long we have treated marine protection as a separate issue to the climate crisis."We must protect our ocean, the biggest carbon sink on earth, and stop burning fossil fuels."And she said: "From mangroves and seagrass meadows, to whales and krill, the oceans biology is one of our best allies in the fight against climate change."But over-exploitation and our addiction to fossil fuels has pushed our ocean to the brink of collapse."We need urgent, concerted action on a global scale to properly protect at least % of our ocean and safeguard its vast stores of blue carbon."Ocean protection is climate action, andwe can save our ocean, it can save us."

title: holding-politicians-account-duty-not-bore
story: Tuesday nightrsquos encounter was not an exact replacement for Kylersquos late and unlamented three ring circus. No-one, as far as I recall, demanded a lie detector test, but had the programme run on past the hour there is no telling where it would have ended up. A brawl in the car park at Pacic Quay perhaps Still, the debate was well worth having,only to produce a sight so rare it is up there with baby pandas and Richard Leonard having a good day on the campaign trail. To wit: Nicola Sturgeon, First Minister of Scotland, being held to account and feeling the heat.: Ferry fiasco as Ministers suedEarlier that day, the results of the  Programme for International Student Assessmentsurvey had been published, and they did not make welcome reading for Scotlandrsquos pupils. Scotlandrsquos educational performance, on which the country has always prided itself ndash rightly or wrongly ndash was revealed to be a dangerously leaning tower. Reading levels were up, but performances in maths and science were falling and at record lows. Lindsay Paterson, professor of education policy at Edinburgh University, described Scotlandrsquos overall performance as ldquostagnating in mediocrity.As well as being taken to task on education, the subject on which she has asked to be judged first and foremost, the First Minister was asked about the state of Scotlandrsquos hospitals."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","description": "Brexit:  days until Britain is scheduled to leave the EU","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer v media iFShJ poster.jpg width","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests iFShJ.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": This was not the first time she had been tackled on the subject on television. There was Andrew Neilrsquos now famous question to her on November  in his BBC show.After stating that only two of eight waiting time targets had been hit, Neil went on: ldquoChildren are dying in a new Glasgow hospital because the water is contaminated, perhaps by pigeon droppings. A new multi-million pound Edinburgh hospital, should have opened in , is still unfit to open. You canrsquot even get the ventilation system to work. Yoursquove got the worst drug addiction problem in Europe but you cut drug treatment budgets by pound million. You clung on to your last health minister, you are under pressure to sack her successor. Yoursquove called for legislation to protect the NHS from Donald Trump. Maybe the NHS needs legislation to protect it from Nicola Sturgeon : Sturgeon acccuses think-tank on analysisIt was a blistering inquiry. To be fair to Ms Sturgeon, she had responses for both Neil last week and her interrogators on Tuesday. To Neil, she pointed out, among other things, the pound million being put into meeting waiting time targets, the public inquiry into the Royal Hospital for Sick Children in Edinburgh, and the ldquoextremely high public satisfaction ratings for the NHS in Scotland. In the STV debate she highlighted the improvement in reading.The question here is not how she performed in both instances. She is an impressive politician, on the national and international stage. But why does it take a General Election for her to be challenged so robustly  Why are there not more such encounters For all Andrew Neilrsquos talents, he did not fall out of a magic interviewer tree. He is smart, fast, has a certain dogged style and command of facts and puts them to good use. Similarly, there was nothing radically dferent about the STV debate, other than the participants were allowed to cross examine each other, an innovation all other televised debates should adopt.There is no doubt that the First Minister regularly puts her record forward for scrutiny. She does it every week at FMQs for starters. It should be noted, too, that like the other party leaders, but not Boris Johnson, she went into the Neil den. He has been frit she was not. Over the past few weeks she has appeared in countless debates and phone-ins.Yet as far as television grillings go, it is only in the Neil interview and the STV debate that she has been robustly held to account.Granted, the notion that Scotlandrsquos First Minister is somehow given an easy ride will be laughable to some. Of the near dozen national daily newspapers in Scotland only one, our sister paper The National, openly backs independence and, by implication, the main party supporting it.Of the rest, as any visit to the newsagents will show, no-one would suspect them of being cheerleaders for the FM, and some are ferocious in their criticism.As for the BBC in Scotland, it comes under frequent attack for alleged bias, a charge it denies.This is not solely about the media, however. It is about a political culture that has become too settled and not questioning enough.In part the failure to hold the FM and her Ministers to account can be put down to the calibre of opposition politicians. A fair number, not all, are simply not good enough. Nor is the Scottish Parliament always sitting when problems arise.: Candidate leaflet defacedI do not believe that the First Minister is given an easier time of it because she is a woman. If anything, the opposite is true.The trouble goes wider than any branch of the media, or inidual politician. A few months ago there was a dust up on Twitter between Muriel Gray and Val McDermid. The row flared over a tweet by the BBCrsquos political editor Laura Kuenssberg and whether or not it showed bias against the FM. Ms McDermid said: ldquoI used to respect you @bbclaurak. Insulting a politician for doing their job, however, reduces that respect to shreds.To which Ms Gray replied: ldquoMocking politicians of all and every party instead of beatying them used to be the norm in Scotland. We were rather good at it. The bedrock of Scots humour. Not sure I even recognise this lsquoworship the great leader or rsquo thing. Itrsquos so not ...Scottish. And so it went on.Did Gray have a point  Is there enough distance in Scotland between the government and the governed, or after so long with one party in power has the situation become cosier than is good for us Every government makes mistakes. All governments can do better. There have to be ways of pointing that out that donrsquot meet with accusations of bias or unfairness. Criticising a Scottish Government ndash of whatever stripe ndash is not criticising Scotland. We forget that at our peril.

title: britons-spend-two-weeks-wages-christmas
story: In total, those questioned plan to spend pound on average on the festivities, including presents, preparations and celebrations with work colleagues.Nationwide Building Society, which released the research, said this amount equates to nearly two weeksrsquo worth of take-home pay, based on average UK wages.Around one in  people plan to spend more than pound on Christmas gts for family members this year, the survey of , people found.Some % of people surveyed by Nationwide Building Society predict they will spend more than this sum on presents alone.On average, people expect to fork out pound on gts for relatives.Children will receive the most expensive presents, the research suggests, with those surveyed predicting they will spend pound per child.More than a quarterof people plan to spend more than pound per child.The next largest amounts of cash will go on spouses and partners, who can expect to receive gts worth pound on average.But one in people admit they will not buy anything for their other half.Men spend an average of pound more on their partner than women, the research suggests.After children and partners, mothers are next in the Christmas gt pecking order, with around pound being spent on them, followed by fathers, who can expect to receive presents worth pound typically.People said they plan to spend pound on average on grandparents, with siblings and in-laws having pound and pound spent on them respectively.Meanwhile, pets will be treated to pound worth of gts typically - just pound less than people plan to spend on their aunts or uncles, at pound on average.Not all giving is voluntary - nearly a quarterof people said they felt pressured into buying Secret Santa presents for colleagues.The research also revealed that more than two-fthsof men do not set a Christmas budget, nor do a thirdof women.People in Wales are least likely to plan, with nearly halfhaving no strategy for their festive spending, the research found.Those in the North East of Englandand Scotlandare also among the most likely to have no budget in place.Guy Simmonds, head of current account customer management at Nationwide, said: ldquoThe cost of Christmas can quickly mount up, with people spending an average of two weeksrsquo salary funding the festive period.ldquoItrsquos incredibly easy to spend more than we can afford, which is why many of us start the new year in debt.ldquoPlanning is vital to sensible spending. We would encourage people to set a budget they can afford and stick to it.

title: superfast-internet-three-years-late
story: It is the latest blow to the ldquoR programme, which has been beset by contractual delays.It puts a question mark over the future of Rural Economy Secretary Fergus Ewing, who last year vowed to quitthe R target date of  was missed.ldquoIf I donrsquot deliver this by , I think it will be time for Fergus Ewing to depart and do something , and leave the job to somebody . But I can assure you, wersquore on the case, he told the Scottish Land and Estates conference.In her  manesto for Holyrood, Nicola Sturgeon promised to ldquodeliver  per cent superfast broadband coverage for Scotland by the end of the next Parliament.Initially set for spring , the target later slipped to the end of . However, a new Scottish Government procurement document says ministers still need ldquokey management resources to assist in the delivery of the Reaching % Programme successfully over the next four years, taking it to .It also says the ldquodeployment tranche could last another year, taking it to .The Government last night refused to put a definitive date on the programme but said it had been Itrsquos time the Government came clean and said exactly what their new target date is.:Superfast internet access for areas in HighlandsHighlands  Islands Tory MSP Edward Mountain said he feared the north of Scotland would not be fully connected to superfast broadband until at least .He added: ldquoIrsquod be happy to lend Fergus Ewing a pen to write his resignation.The Government said: ldquoBy confirming BT plc as the preferred bidder for all three geographic lots, we have taken a signicant step towards completing the procurement process.ldquoAs with any procurement of this scale, the process is a complex one and we have had to build in a degree of flexibility to respond to a range of circumstances.ldquoThis has included extending timelines and allowing for a pause at key parts of the process at the request of the bidders.ldquoThis contract is for the resourcing of the R delivery team. title: scottishpower-unveils-plans-put-solar-panels-next-wind-turbines
story: The move ndash revealed at the global climate emergency summit in Madrid ndash marks a major breakthrough for renewable electricity in the country as it will be produced even when the wind does not blow and will instead harness the light.However, the announcement for a mass roll-out of Chinese and Korean  comes amid growing concerns about whether Scottish manufacturing can capitalise on the green industrial revolution.There are growing fears for jobs at CS Wind, a factory in Campbeltown which makes the towers for wind farms.Twenty-two people lost their livelihoods this week and more are at risk.Unite, the trade union, has called for Scottish Government help but ministers believe they are limited in what they can do because of EU state aid rules.Speaking at COP in Madrid, Keith Anderson, the chief executive of ScottishPower, said: ldquoEvery green megawatt of electricity will be crucialwe stand any chance of hitting lsquonet zerorsquo in , so innovation from energy companies is more important than ever.ldquoThis means squeezing the absolute maximum potential out of every clean energy project that we consider. In the UK and Ireland the perfect blend of clean power from onshore renewables should include a mixture of clean energy technologies.ldquoThe costs for building wind, solar and batteries have reduced considerably in recent years, and they complement each other very well.ldquoThey perform best at dferent times of the day and at dferent times of the year.Glasgow ranks as one of Europersquos darkest cities, but much of Scotland enjoys long, light days in the summer, when there is less wind.:Gas-addicted Scots have Europes worst record on renewable heatMr Anderson added: ldquoAs well as retrofitting additional technologies to existing sites, as we are already doing, our strategy going forward will see us deliver hybrid projects as standard.ldquoIn the next  months I believe that hybrids will be the new normal for all renewable energy developers.ScottishPower is owned by Spanish giant Iberdrola, which has invested in major solar power stations, in places more associated with the sun than Scotland. Putting solar, battery and wind resources together should reduce both the impact and cost of such developments.ScottishPower said planning applications had already been submitted to add solar technology to the existing wind farms in Cornwall, Lancashire and Cambridgeshire in England. It will now add projects in Scotland andIreland too.The company is currently developing , megawatts of new onshore wind projects.It said most of these would now also have batteries and solar , or a mixture of both.The new strategy comes one year after ScottishPower became the first integrated energy company in the UK to solely generate  per cent renewable energy.In the wider Iberdrola group, solar is already a prominent feature in Spain, the US, Mexico and Brazil.This includes the MW Nuacutentildeez de Balboa solar scheme in the south of Spain, the largest solar project currently under construction in Europe.The Scottish Government has already approved plans for a  megawatt battery at the UKrsquos largest wind farm, Whitelee, outside Glasgow.Scotland has long been tipped as a renewable energy powerhouse, though more because of its wind and tides than because of its sunshine.Bids by both Glasgow and Edinburgh to become Britainrsquos first net-zero carbon cities have sparked hopes that jobs will follow.Labour has tried to claim the phrase green industrial revolution as it talks up manufacturing jobs in the UK.But other parties are also enthusiastic about the potential for economic growth.However, so far the UK and Scotland have struggled to secure contracts to build kit for renewable energy.Controversy has focused around the future of yards owned by BiFab.Unite has been at the forefront of campaigning for Scottish facilities and for factories including the BiFab yards in Arnish and Fe to benefit from the ldquogreen manufacturing revolution.BiFab builds large-scale equipment for the offshore oil and gas industry, as well as s for offshore wind turbines and tidal generators.It was rescued from the brink of administration by the Scottish Government in a pound million agreement in  before being purchased by Canadian firm DF Barnes last April, although hundreds of jobs were shed.

title: open-university-launches-first-scots-language-course
story: Developed over the past two years by The Open Universityand Education Scotland along with the Scots community, the free online course teaches the language through the context in which it is spoken.It also highlights the role of the language in Scottish culture and society.Taking around  hours to complete, it is intended to help grow knowledge and understanding of Scots and its history, in Scotland and further afield.:Scottish Gaelic Duolingo app accrues , users in just one weekIt has been hailed as a "signicant step forward in the continued recognition" of the language.The course is split into two parts and the first part is now available on the OUs OpenLearn Create , with the second expected to be online by the end of the month.The creators hoped the course will be used in the classroom by teachers and other educators.Sylvia Warnecke, OU senior lecturer in languages, said: "As Scots grows in popularity, it feels right to show how as a language it has developed over time as a vital aspect of Scottish culture and history, and how it links to other European languages."The course is written to appeal both to existing Scots speakers and those new to the language."It will give learners a chance to practise using the language themselves and develop their understanding of written and spoken Scots in dferent dialects.":What a boorach! The Scots words you need to get you through the next few weeksMichael Dempster, Scots Scriever at the National Library of Scotland, said: "As a first language Scots speaker and someone who teaches other speakers about their language, this course is a signicant step forward in the continued recognition and understanding of our language."This is an excellent resource for both Scots speakers and learners, gie it a shot."Author James Robertson, co-founder of Scots language publishers Itchy Coo, was among those who contributed to the course.He said: "This comprehensive course underlines the range, vitality and national signicance of Scots."It shows what a crucial and integral part of Scottish culture and identity Scots has been and continues to be."

title: air-new-zealand-trials-edible-coffee-cups
story: The cups are baked from a biscuit base, are vanilla-flavoured, leak-proof and can double as a dessert bowl.Nike Chave, of the airline, said while the company - which serves more than eight million cups of coffee a year - has been using compostable, plant-based cups for some time, it was aiming to "remove these totally from landfills"."Weve been working in partnership with innovative New Zealand company twiice to explore the future of edible coffee cups," Ms Chave said in a statement released by the airline."The cups have been a big hit with the customers who have used these and weve also been using the cups as dessert bowls."Ms Chave says the airline would continue to trial the edible coffee cups and would work with twiice and others to explore options that could make it a viable long-term product for the airline.Twiice says the cup will not crumble like a biscuit, and will "stay crisp at least as long as it takes to drink your coffee, and longer"."Its terric that Air New Zealand has partnered with us to showcase to its customers and the world that a little bit of Kiwi ingenuity and innovation could have a really positive impact on the environment while at the same time delivering a really cool and tasty customer experience," twiice founder Jamie Cashmore said.

title: nuclear-industry-makes-big-pitch-uk-expansion-green-alternative
story: The Nuclear Industry Associationannual conference in London will highlight the need for a "proven, dependable" source of low-carbon electricity generation alongside growth in solar and wind power.Industry leaders will argue that without this, the country risks embedding a major reliance on carbon-emitting gas-fired power stations "for generations to come".Three out of four of , adults surveyed to coincide with the conference said they want the UK Government to take more action to reduce CO emissions.Tom Greatrex, chief executive of the NIA, said: "We have to grow the industrys contribution to a low-carbon economy."This is a proven, dependable technology with lower lecycle CO emissions than solar power and the same as offshore wind. title: brian-beacom-vote-look-panto-stage-inspiration
story: Yes, the election is soon to be with us, and we the audience, sorry, the voters, are faced with decisions way more dficult than the dim and gullible Snow White ever had to contend with.Butwe canrsquot make a choice between the parties begging for our X, why not look to panto for the answers  The panto stage is bathed in the brightest lights of morality, itrsquos a world in which truth triumphs over lies, love over hate and good over evil. However, the question you have to ask yourself is will our political leaders appropriate the values of panto heroes ndash or are they villains Boris Johnson is clearly a shoo-in for the role of Pinocchio, a man whose nose must have extended every time he maintained his party will build  new hospitals and hire , new nurses, that Jeremy Corbyn wants to scrap M, and that hersquod loved to have chatted with Andrew Neilndash except he was in hospital that day having a backbone inserted. The Geppetto pulling his strings is most certainly Dominic Cummings. But you have to ask will the current Prime Minister ever turn into a real boy Jeremy Corbyn could easily be reimagined as Jack of the Beanstalk fame. Not too brightour bearded Jack is prepared to gamble on the dream his magic beans will grow and form a classless society and the rich will simply surrender their wealth and power.Corbyn is confident he can slay the giant corporations, the multi-nationals, the evil bankers. And he is well cast, blessed in the sense hersquos already used to angry voices, the Remainers who smell the blood of this Englishman who claims to be a European and the British Jews who canrsquot believe he canrsquot apologise.But can Jack kill the giant and contain the Glaxo-Klein invaders, whom he says will wreck our NHS  His greatest threat could be his own mum, the very simple Dame Trot, a woman who knows him intimately, has little appreciation of numbers or value systems ndash who must be played by Dianne Abbott. This real-le Trot once said she was in primary school aged . Imagine the Princess being played by John McDonnell, whom Jack truly loves, and one day the pair will live together in a kingdom in which the Rothschilds are banished and hikes in corporation tax are plentul. Richard Leonard will play the little servant boy.Aladdin  Itrsquos Nicola Sturgeon of course, the little street urchin who finds a magic lamp, rubs it hard like shersquos polishing her Kurt Geiger high heels and out pops a wise-cracking, laugh-a-minute Genie,who grants him three wishes. But itrsquos all the same wish. Independence. Independence. And independence.The Genie doesnrsquot say what will happen after these three wishes are used up but one day Abanazar appearswho demands to know what Aladdin will do during the next  years of economic misery, how he will create a new currency and set limits on immigration ndash while dealing with the cost of keeping Widow Twankey and her sisters in one of Old Pekingrsquos residential care centres.Princess Jasmine is most certainly finance minister Derek Mackay, who will fund their palace with PFI money but we wonrsquot expect Aladdin to fly too often on his magic carpet, given climate change-enforced air travel restriction, instead restricted to one flight a year. And Widow Twankeywill be around to make sure Aladdin behaves.Finally, Jo Swinson could well be a stand-out in Cinderella. But not playing the scullery scrubber who eventually meets her prince. Swinson seems better cast as an Ugly Sister, a loud performer, yet unattractive to voters who canrsquot bear the thought of another referendum.Swinson will no doubt sees herself as Cinders, the empowered woman capable of rising to the very top ndash she even had Hugh Grant lined up to play the part of the Prince ndash but since then Grant has claimed hersquos better in the wings.What happens to this Ugly Sister whose feet donrsquot fit the slipper of public expectation  Shersquoll hope to be taken to live in the palace in exchange for voting support.Does all this help  Not a bit  Well, forget voting and go see a panto. At least the heroes and the evil queens giants princesses are just a little more easy to identy. And the worst that can happen is a little ham acting.

title: susan-deacons-resignation-letter-humza-yousaf-spa-chair-stands
story: Susan Deacon, who held the role for two years, said she believed Scotlands police governance was "fundamentally flawed"Her departure comes after widespread suggestions - even from PoliceScotland- that her board was not doing a good job at scrutinising the force.:Police Scotland watchdog Susan Deacon resignsBut Ms Deacon, in a blistering resignation letter to the Justice Secretary,suggested the current system could not be made to work.Read her resignation letter toHumza Yousafin full below:Dear HumzaI write to tender my resignation as Chair of the Scottish Police Authority.I consider it a privilege to have played a part in developing and strengthening policing in Scotland and I am pleased that I leave this role with our police service in a much stronger place than it was when I was first appointed, exactly two years ago.I have, as you have frequently acknowledged, worked tirelessly to try and ensure that the SPA operates effectively, and that public confidence and trust in policing is maintained. I have also made every effort to attempt to make the existing statutory framework operate as I believe it was intended.In truth, however, I have increasingly become convinced that the governance and accountability arrangements for policing in Scotland are fundamentally flawed, in structure, culture and practice, and I conclude that there is little more I can do to make these arrangements work effectively. I would suggest that the Scottish Government thinks afresh about how the police service is scrutinised and held to account and how, or , a better separation between politics and policing, and indeed between the police service and those who oversee it, can be achieved. I would be pleased to share my thoughts and reflections on these matters with you, and indeed with the Scottish Parliamentrsquos Justice Committee, at any time.May I thank you for the opportunity to have served in this role and hope that our police service continues to develop effectively in the future.Kind regardsSusan Deacon CBE

title: stop-spread-norovirus
story: They include rapidly feeling sick, projectile vomiting and watery diarrhoea.People may also experience a high temperature, a headache and aching arms and legs.Symptoms usually clear within two days but adults and children are advised not toto work or school until  hours after symptoms have passed.:Poll: Most Scots think SNP handling NHS badlyThose affected should drink lots of fluids, such as water or squash, while they are ill and only eatthey want to, according to official NHS advice.Babies who have the bug should receive their usual feeds but possibly smaller amounts at more regular intervals.People who are sick or elderly are especially vulnerable to catching the bug, so anyone who has experienced vomiting or diarrhoea is advised to not visit elderly or poorly relatives, particularlythey are in hospital.Alcohol gels and rubs do not kill norovirus ndash the best way to stop the bug spreading is by washing hands frequently with soap and water.:Winter vomiting bug fears shuts two Scottish schoolsNorovirus can be caught by coming into close contact with an infected person and by touching surfaces or objects that have the virus on them, then touching the mouth.It is also possible to catch norovirus through eating food that has been prepared or handled by somebody with the bug.To clean the house, people are advised to use bleach and hot water or a cleaner with bleach in it.Cleaning should focus on commonly used objects such as toilets, taps, telephones, door handles and kitchen surfaces.Bedding and contaminated clothing can be washed at C to kill the bug.

story: Opinion polls continue to suggest the Conservative Party enjoys a comfortable lead over Labour.The latest poll averages put the Tories on %, with Labour on %, the Liberal Democrats on %, the Brexit Party on % and the Greens on %.But what are the chances of the polls shting decisively between now and election day At this point in the  election campaign, the polls showed the Conservatives on %, with Labour on %, the Lib Dems on %, Ukip on % and the Greens on %.:Labour accused of failing to investigate antisemitism casesBut on election day, the Tories finished on % ndash one point below where they had been a week earlier ndash while Labour had risen six points to %.The Lib Dems were still on %, while both Ukip and the Greens finished on %.The change was enough to deny the Tories a majority and produce a hung parliament.There was movement in  as well, albeit on a smaller scale and with dferent consequences.One week before polling day in , the Tories were averaging % and Labour %, with Ukip on %, the Lib Dems on % and the Greens on %.These figures pointed to a hung parliament ndash but come election day, the Tories opened up a seven-point lead over Labour to finish on % while Labour ended on %.:Jo Swinson suggests she will not work with SNP for Peoples Voteprice tag is indyrefUkip, the Lib Dems and Greens finished on %, % and % respectively.This was enough to give the Conservatives a small overall majority in Parliament.The pattern in  and  suggests that what the polls are showing one week from election day is not necessarily the best guide to what will happen on election day itself.It also serves as a reminder that polls are not predictions, merely snapshots of opinion at a certain point in time.ndash All figures quoted above are for vote shares in Great Britain

title: clan gathering brings together support team
story: A north-east charity held its biannual meeting in Aberdeen recently.CLAN Cancer Support board members, staff and volunteers met at CLAN House, CLAN’s head office in Aberdeen, with guests coming from as far north as Lerwick and Kirkwall as well as from Elgin, Ballater, Turrf and Crimond.The gathering, which takes place in the spring and autumn each year, gives all the people involved in bringing cancer support to clients the opportunity to share experiences, learn about new initiatives and celebrate the positive impact the charity had had on with people affected by cancer.At the event, CLAN CEO Dr Colette Backwell shared the latest CLAN news and staff and volunteers had the opportunity to ask questions of CLAN’s trustees and board members in a Question Time style event.Dr Backwell said: “We live in such a fast-paced, busy society these days, which makes it hard to engage with everyone regularly, especially with CLAN’s widespread workforce across the north-east, Moray, Orkney and Shetland. That is why it is so important for our team to come together to celebrate our successes, learn from each other and connect as an organisation.“We’re incredibly proud to have supported over , people in the last year, more than half of which were new clients. The children and families’ team provided support on over , occasions. It’s a fantastic opportunity to thank everyone who helps make this possible and to motivate everyone to continue and surpass the excellent levels of support they provide across the region.“The number of cancers being diagnosed continues to rise, and every year it is estimated that over , people in Scotland are told they have cancer. However, more people than ever are living beyond a cancer diagnosis, which places even greater need for CLAN’s wellbeing, emotional and practical support services.”CLAN Cancer Support is an independent charity which provides comfort, support and information, free of charge, for anyone, of any age, affected by any type of cancer. CLAN aims to support people to reduce anxiety, stress and to increase their ability to cope with the effects of a serious illness. CLAN supports those who have a cancer diagnosis, as well as their friends and family members.Based in Aberdeen, the charity covers the whole of north-east Scotland, Moray, Orkney and Shetland.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.ellontimes webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"The new Woof Top sensory garden at the Scottish SPCAs Drumoak centre"  Sensory garden unveiled by Scottish SPCA viewBox"  . ." enable-background"new   . ." xml:space"preserve"c,,.-,.-.c-,-.,.-.C.,.,,,,.z"  Coremetrics  Coremetrics  Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"Coremetrics.articleTeaserEventCatID  "ELLO | Article Teaser"

title: rail timetable improvements
story: ScotRail will deliver a boost for customers throughout the country, with more seats, more services, and a brand-new station as it introduces its new timetable.The rail operator announced the changes to the timetable will come into effect from Sunday, December .A new timetable between Inverurie, Dyce and Aberdeen will provide more than  per cent more services and there will now be up to three trains per hour between these stations, plus more direct journeys across Aberdeenshire between Inverurie, Stonehaven and Montrose.The changes will see the addition of four new peak time services.More services have also been created between Montrose and Inverurie, increasing from the existing five to  direct services per day.This follows the completion of the major improvements to the Aberdeen to Inverness line, with Network Rail successfully delivering more than  miles of new rail as part of a project to transform journeys for customers in this part of the country.Further timetable improvements will be delivered in May and December .David Simpson, ScotRail Operations Director, said: “The improvements we are making to our timetable from December will deliver even more benefits for our customers, delivering more seats, more services, and a new station in the north east of Glasgow.“The £ million investment in new and upgraded trains and the infrastructure improvements across the country are all part of building the best railway Scotland has ever had.”Bill Reeve, Transport Scotland’s Director of Rail added: “Passengers will welcome many of the changes up and down the country, particularly the additional services in the north east and the new Robroyston station just outside Glasgow.“This shows our signicant investment is delivering more seats and more services than ever before.”For more details visit www.scotrail.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: retail plans at former health centre site
story: Proposals for a new retail development in Inverurie town centre have been submitted to Aberdeenshire Council.Aberdeen-based developer West Coast Estates has been working on the plans with the National Health Service.The development would see the site of the former Inverurie Health Centre transformed into a new retail destination that will complement the existing shops currently available in the town.The proposals, which would see the current building demolished and the vacant town centre site regenerated, would feature four new retail units, including a Starbucks drive thru - the first for the town and only the second of its kind in Aberdeenshire.Developer West Coast Estates say the proposals have been “carefully developed to respect neighbouring properties, utilise its fantastic location and add to the unique character of the town”.West Coast Estates director Iftikar Mian said: “The proposal presents an excellent opportunity to breathe new le into a vacant site in a key location in the town, one that will benefit local residents, and importantly, complement the existing retail offer that is avaialble in Inverurie.“Importantly, and recognising the current need for additional car parking spaces within the town centre, the proposals would also deliver  much needed new car parking spaces.“Discussions are already underway with a iety of operators, including Starbucks, and we look forward to working with the local community, neighbouring businesses, and all those who have an interest in the proposals.”The development would see a total investment of £ million.It is also estimated that it would create up to  full and part-time job opportunities.data-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: sensory garden unveiled by scottish spca
story: The Scottish SPCA has unveiled a new sensory garden for dogs at their Aberdeenshire Animal Rescue and Rehoming Centre thanks to generous funding from craft beer giants, BrewDog.Local boxing champion Lee McAllister was there on the day to show his support.Acting centre manager Louise Griese said: “The idea behind the garden is to provide dogs with sensory stimulation they will never have experienced before.“The garden is full of dferent scents, and in the summer months there will be dog friendly plants, which encourage them to use their senses and provides mental stimulation within the surroundings. “The garden also includes dferent surfaces and textures which create an element of fun for the dogs, as well as many other objects and obstacles to provide exercise and to keep the dogs entertained. “We’ve designed this area to incorporate as many dferent experiences for the dogs as possible including a safe, quiet space for them to relax in. “Our centre in Glasgow opened their sensory garden last year and the team have witnessed positive changes in the confidence levels of the dogs.“It was a real team effort involving the local community. story: With posties across the country bracing themselves for the usual bumper festive postbag, Royal Mail is urging customer to help out by posting early this year.The last posting date for Christmas mail sent second class is Wednesday, December  while for first class mail it’s Friday, December .The cut-off for special delivery mail is Monday, December .However,you’re sending mail overseas, the last posting dates are earlier in the month.The latest recommended posting date is for mail to Africa, Asia, Caribbean, Central  South America, the Far East, and the Middle East is Monday, December .Those wanting to send cards or gts to Cyprus and Malta should post no later than Tuesday, December .For Eastern Europecards and gts should be sent no later than Wednesday, December .Those wishing to send festive greetings to friends and family in Australia, New Zealand, Greece or Turkey, will need to make sure everything is good to go by Thursday, December .Letters and parcels to Canada, Czech Republic, Italy, Poland, Finland, Sweden and the USA should be posted no later than Saturday, December , to arrive in time for Christmas.Festive greetings being sent to Austria, Denmark, Germany, Iceland, Netherlands, Norway, Portugal, Slovakia, Spain and Switzerland will need to be in the mail by Monday, December .Season’s Greetings going to Belgium, France, Ireland and Luxembourg should be posted by Wednesday, December .The last posting dates apply to both standard international services and those which have tracking and signature.Further information is available at Royal Mail Christmas Postdata-src"https:images-o.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.inverurieherald webimage ..! title: the burning issue is biomass energy as green as it appears
story: The number of Scottish power plants burning trees or plant material to generate renewable energy has quadrupled since . The energy produced is enough to power an estimated , homes, but environmentalists claim biomass energy isn’t as green as it appears.Scotlands biomass sites generate enough energy to power , homes.When people think of clean energy, wind turbines and solar  often come to mind.But biomass power plants – a less well-known method of generating renewable electricity – are booming across the UK and environmental campaigners have raised doubts about their green credentials.The burning of trees or plant matter – known as plant biomass – now accounts for more than a fth of the UK’s renewable energy, second only to wind power.The number of plant biomass power plants in the UK has more than trebled in four years, from  in  to  in .Between them, they now produce enough energy to power around . million homes, analysis by the JPIMedia Data Unit has found.In Scotland, the number has quadrupled from  biomass sites in  to  by . Unlike other forms of green energy, biomass plants produce greenhouse gases. Across the country, the rise in biomass means its total greenhouse gas emissions have nearly reached the amount produced by coal. The industry says wood is sourced from renewable forests, with new trees being planted which store carbon and help to offset the emissions produced.But with the environment proving a key policy battleground in this year’s General Election, campaigners are calling for the practice to come under more scrutiny.Katja Garson, forest and climate campaigner at European campaign group Fern, said: “It is very concerning that in the global push to reduce emissions, more is not being said about the climate impacts of harvesting and burning wood.” Critics have also raised concerns that some power plants ship wood in from overseas, saying this has an added impact on the environment.data-src"https:images-e.jpimedia.uk imagefetch w_auto,f_auto,ar_:,q_auto:low,c_fill _h_lte_,c_mfit,h_ https:www.fraserburghherald webimage ..! image image.jpg" class"article-suggested-teaser__image cld-responsive" alt"Controversial baby names."
